headline: Uriah Rennie had to think quickly when Roy Keane 'suddenly snapped' to stop a '20-man brawl'
body: Ex-Premier League referee Uriah Rennie is remembered not just for breaking racial barriers in English football, but for his presence, poise and occasional physical authority during high-stakes matches. The trailblazing official, who died aged 65 on Sunday, was once forced to step in to physically restrain Roy Keane during a heated clash between Manchester United and Sunderland in August 2002.
The fixture turned volatile when Keane, under intense scrutiny following his explosive World Cup walk-out that summer, got into a fiery confrontation with Ireland team-mate Jason McAteer.
Throughout the match, the pair had been dishing out tough tackles and verbal jabs, with Liverpool-born McAteer mocking Keane's newly released autobiography.

Tempers flared quickly, and soon the situation threatened to spiral out of control. Spotting "fury" in Keane's eyes after a coming together between the players, Rennie stepped in to calm him down. A martial arts expert, the referee didn't hesitate, earning a degree of respect from the notoriously hard-to-please United skipper in the process.

In his 2022 book Your Show, a novelisation of his refereeing career, Rennie recalled the tense moment with vivid detail. "They both tumble onto the turf. Limbs flailing. Elbows and knees," he wrote. "Roy's reacting now, fury in his eyes, head's gone. This feud has history... grab Roy, save Jason?"

Rennie's instincts then took over. "Only a moment to think. You take matters in your own giant black hands with a cliff-edged ­fearlessness. You get in between the two. You do what you have to do, to stop it escalating, from turning into a 20-man mass brawl," he explained. "You grab Roy, grip onto his shirt like you did a few ­seasons ago at White Hart Lane, but tighter."

His intervention was effective. Keane, visibly seething, was separated from McAteer. Both players, in their own way, acknowledged the impact – McAteer later admitted that Keane would have "ripped his head off" if Rennie hadn't come between them. Keane, though never one to show deference, seemed to develop a level of respect for the referee's fearless handling of the moment.

However, just minutes later, Keane lashed out again – this time catching McAteer with a sharp elbow to the back of the head. Rennie immediately issued a red card – a decision so clear-cut that even Sir Alex Ferguson didn't contest it.

"The referee had no choice but to send him off," the legendary United manager said after the game. "Roy is the first United player to be sent off for this offence and I have said recently the use of the elbow is a growing problem in our game." He later confirmed that the club would not appeal the decision and had fined Keane £150,000.

Rennie admitted his handling of the situation went beyond standard procedure: "I didn't follow FA protocol," he wrote. "You throw away the rule book and intervene early with action, words won’t do, stopping Keane from doing something he shouldn't.

"You stare Keane dead in the eyes, still clutching a fistful of his shirt... messy Irish ­history. Messy World Cup history. Keane is fiddling with his captain's armband as you ­reason with him. He's only half listening, facing you but eyeing up the Sunderland player who has retreated behind you to safety. Although he might not be showing it now, maybe in his own way, he respects you."

Despite being sent off, Keane remained unapologetic. Speaking on the Stick to Football podcast in 2023, he insisted McAteer "deserved" the elbow and that the two were "absolutely not" on speaking terms. "He was one of those players who couldn't stop running their mouths," Keane said. "I didn't mind lads kicking me or booting me but McAteer as usual had plenty to say for himself."

McAteer, who had also played for Liverpool, Bolton, and Blackburn, later described their relationship as "toxic." He didn't hold back in his own assessment, calling Keane a "clown" and telling him to "bore off."

headline: Man Utd striker transfer on brink of collapse after hint on future and strict demands
body: Rasmus Hojlund looks set to stay at Manchester United with clubs struggling to meet the Red Devils’ demands. The Danish forward was linked with a move away from Old Trafford after an awful season.

Hojlund scored just four Premier League goals for United last term, leading to suggestions that the former Atalanta striker could return to Italy. Inter Milan were among the sides linked with him, while Juventus and Napoli were also credited with interest.
But it appears that a move to Serie A is no longer an option according to reports. According to suggestions in Italy, United’s demands of a permanent Deal have made a move very difficult.
It is reported that United want to receive around £40m for the 22-year-old, a deal that the Italian sides would struggle to put together. They would only be able to sign him on loan as it stands.

Hojlund has recently spoken out on his future at Old Trafford and confirmed that he was looking to stay with the club. He said: “I have a contract until 2030, so I expect to play for Manchester United. I'm looking forward to going on a summer vacation, and then I'm fully dedicated to the project that's underway.

"I know I can't get much out of reading things. I know what the facts are, and that is that I have a contract with Manchester United until 2030. I expect to play there, so I'm just getting ready for some summer vacation and then hopefully a good pre-season."

In all, Hojlund has made 95 appearances for United since his £72m move from Atalanta. In that time, he has scored just 26 goals. Former Red Devils star Phil Jones has suggested that a move away from the club might be best for his career.
He said: "It’s a difficult one, I feel really sorry for him (Hojlund). It's obviously been a difficult season for him, but I always find it's difficult for a No. 9 in a difficult season.
"He's probably not getting the chances, you know, the seven, eight chances a game. He's feeding off one or two that might come into him in the 70th minute, and he's got to produce.
"It hasn't quite happened for him yet. It's been difficult for him, but I think if he were to move on, he would probably benefit from that. A bit like Marcus (Rashford), it's a fresh start for him.

"It's a difficult one for Rasmus Hojlund. What I would say is, I think that Man United will be looking for another No. 9. Maybe that would take a bit of the pressure off him as well if he can manage his minutes between the two No. 9s."

headline: Manchester United cannot afford to repeat transfer mistake with dream summer signing
body: The start of Manchester United's pre-season campaign will be here before we know it.

United are scheduled to play the opening game of their pre-season programme on Saturday, July 19, facing Leeds United in Stockholm. They will then travel to the United States for their pre-season tour a few days later.

United will play three games in the US, facing West Ham United, Everton and Bournemouth as part of the Premier League Summer Series. After returning to home soil, they will wrap up their pre-season schedule with a clash against Fiorentina at Old Trafford.

This will mark the third summer in a row that United have jetted off to the US for their pre-season tour. On the previous two, with the exception of just one game, United have been starved of an out-and-out centre-forward.

Rasmus Hojlund arrived from Atalanta in August 2023 after United had returned from the US and he got injured in the opening game of last summer's pre-season tour, meaning he has not had a full pre-season since arriving at Old Trafford.

He will desperately be hoping it is third time lucky for him this summer, although Inter Milan's interest in his signature could see him shipped out of Old Trafford before United board their flight to the US in the fourth week of July.

With United prepared to sell any player this summer, they are unlikely to stand in the 22-year-old's way if an enticing offer is presented to them. He scored just ten goals in 2024/25 and patience with him is wearing increasingly thin.

Whether Hojlund departs or not, it is no secret by now that United are desperate to sign a striker. However, after missing out on Liam Delap, it remains to be seen which direction that search will head in.

They continue to be linked with the likes of Sporting Lisbon's Viktor Gyokeres and Victor Osimhen of Napoli, with both seemingly destined to move this summer, but no formal offers for a striker have yet been tabled by the Reds, with their focus currently on trying to sign Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford.

United have already strengthened their attack by signing Matheus Cunha from Wolves for £62.5million, and Mbeumo is likely to command a similar fee, but ending the summer without recruiting an out-and-out No.9 can't be an option.
The transfer window will temporarily close at 7pm this evening (Tuesday), but will reopen again as soon as next Monday.

Once the window reopens, United need to try and step up their efforts in the seller's market. They want exits to reach double figures this summer and they have a crop of players within their ranks they want to sell who could bring in useful fees.

United have identified Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony as priority sales, while Alejandro Garnacho has been informed he can leave. Selling any player is an easier-said-than-done task, of course, but if United were to successfully offload the aforementioned quartet, they would be looking to bank over £100m.

That would give them a huge boost in their quest to sign a striker. Gyokeres is set to cost north of £60m and he is currently looking as though he could be the most likely candidate to strengthen Ruben Amorim's front line.

Whether it be Gyokeres or an alternative centre-forward, it would be ideal if United could get a deal wrapped up in time to take their new chief goalscorer on the pre-season tour. That adaptation period can be so crucial for players ahead of the competitive action kicking off in August.

Getting a new striker in ahead of the season starting would give Amorim the opportunity to see how he bonds and forms on-field relationships with his new teammates. United were playing catch-up in 2023 and Joshua Zirkzee did not go on last summer's pre-season tour after being granted a period of leave following his participation at Euro 2024 with the Netherlands.

With the Club World Cup taking place over the coming weeks, the summer break is bound to feel as though it is going that little bit quicker. It means the clock is ticking for United to secure their most important jigsaw piece.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Viktor Gyokeres twist, Bryan Mbeumo 'hijack', Victor Osimhen message
body: Hello and welcome back to the Manchester United transfer blog on Tuesday, June 10.

The first portion of this summer's transfer window will close later today and it has already been a very busy nine days for Ruben Amorim. The £62.5million arrival of Matheus Cunha has been confirmed and several further incomings are being targeted and are therefore expected.
Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo is one of those with United seeing bids rejected and now the impending appointment of Thomas Frank at Tottenham could impact that deal.

United are also on the hunt for a new striker with Viktor Gyokeres of Sporting CP now appearing to be their top target. Contact has been made to gauge what it would take to sign him. Victor Osimhen is another name that has been linked with a move to Old Trafford and he has since sent a new message.
Elsewhere, multiple exits are considered very likely with Alejandro Garnacho one of the top candidates set to depart and updates on potential clubs that could sign him have emerged.
Stay tuned to all the latest news from United's summer transfer window below...
Man United submitted their retained list on Monday afternoon, confirming the departure of nine players.

United had already confirmed Jonny Evans, Victor Lindelof and Christian Eriksen would be leaving the club when their deals expire on June 30. Tom Heaton was also not on the retained list but the club have said contract talks with the veteran goalkeeper are ongoing.

Academy players Hubert Graczyk, Jack Kingdon, Sam Murray, Tom Myles, James Nolan and Tom Wooster will be released when their contracts expire this summer, taking the total number of confirmed departures up to nine.
Matheus Cunha is United's only new recruit so far this summer, but the club is working on a deal to sign Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo.
Read more here.
According to Portuguese newspaper A Bola, Gyokeres has made it clear he intends to leave Estadio Jose Alvalade this summer.

He reportedly believes that, after his contributions over the past couple of years, his departure would not harm Sporting. Despite receiving 'better proposals' last summer, the Swede chose to remain in Lisbon.
Now, at 27, he is said to feel that the time is right to take the next step in his career.
Read more here.
There is no progress expected to be made with Bryan Mbeumo today.
Last week, United submitted an opening offer of £45million with a further £10million in add-ons, but it fell short of Brentford’s valuation.

The summer transfer window closes this evening before re-opening due to the Club World Cup and no advancement with Mbeumo is expected before today’s deadline, so you can relax and go outside for a walk.
United would still like to get a deal wrapped up as soon as possible and confirmation of a second bid could arrive shortly after the window opens again on June 16.
With thr FIFA Club World Cup taking place this summer, the usual lull us football fans experience in June and early-July will go a lot quicker than usual this year.
It means pre-season will be here before we know it and preparations for the 2025/26 campaign will soon be stepped up. For United, this summer, of course, is huge.

They have made a solid start to the summer, signing Matheus Cunha and declaring their interest in Bryan Mbeumo, but the addition of a striker remains to important. That is why, in an ideal world, United could do with securing the services of a No.9 before they head off on their tour of the US towards the end of July.
Click here to read more from United writer George Smith.
The Swedish striker has taken a drastic step on social media ahead of ever increasing links to Man United.

While this is merely the first, elementary step towards signing the striker, it appears that Gyokeres has added more hope for Reds fans this week. As first spotted by Portuguese outlet Record, Gyokeres has removed all references to Sporting and Sweden from his Instagram bio.
Previously, the striker mentioned that he represented both clubs, but now it merely states that he is a 'Sportsperson'.

Gyokeres last posted on the social media platform last week when he thanked his friends, family and followers for their birthday wishes. This post was immediately hijacked by United fans asking him to join their club this summer.
The 25-year-old had a successful time at Dortmund before making the move to United in 2021. Sancho also returned to Dortmund on loan last year where he got to the Champions League final.
The report adds that his his days at M16 are coming to an end.
James Nolan has said a "massive thank you" to Manchester United after leaving the club.
Nolan spent last season on loan with Inverness Caledonian Thistle in Scottish League One - where he made 33 appearances - and he will now look for a new club for his next chapter.
Writing on Instagram, Nolan said: "My time at Manchester United has now come to an end.

"From joining at the age of seven to now leaving at 19 it has been my second home. I just want to say a massive thank you to the coaches, players and everyone at the club for making my time unforgettable. I’ve made memories to last a life time. Once a Red always a Red."
Donnarumma insists he wants to stay at Paris Saint-Germain, despite reports linking him to Man United.

With his contract set to expire in the summer of 2026, that has led to a rising uncertainty over his future in Paris, attracting the attention of a number of top clubs. He has emerged as a candidate to replace Andre Onana.

Meanwhile, Director Giovanni Manna said: "He feels good in Paris, we're at the European champion club, so we have no complaints. We are working on a renewal. I have never ruled out interest from the top Italian clubs, but there has never been a negotiation, let's see.

"He is still young, I have to squeeze him for at least another 10 years. At the moment, however, it is very difficult to see Donnarumma in the Italian championship, I'm not just talking about numbers but also about the sporting project. In Italy, beyond Inter who reached the Champions League final, there are Milan and Juve who are struggling, they are in the process of reorganizing: these factors are fundamental."
Gyokeres' stance amid reported transfer interest from Man United has emerged.

A fresh update has emerged in Portuguese news outlet Record about Gyokeres' future. The report claims that the striker is not happy with the Sporting hierarchy amid continued speculation about his future.

It has been reported that Sporting are asking for a higher fee that what the club is said to have promised Gyokeres to allow the striker to leave this summer. The Sweden international has a €100million (£84million) release clause in his contract but has been reported to be available for €70million (£60million).

However, it has now been suggested that Sporting are seeking a fee closer to €80million (£67.4million). This, the report claims, has made Gyokeres "furious" after the aforementioned agreement with the club.
Rasmus Hojlund could be leaving Manchester United in the summer transfer window.
A return to Italy is the most likely outcome with Inter president Giuseppe Marotta already revealing that his team do have an interest in bringing Hojlund to the San Siro.

Transfer plans for the Serie A and Champions League runners-up now look set to be finalised with Cristian Chivu confirmed as the replacement for Simone Inzaghi. With that situation resolved, a decision on Hojlund should now come.
Tottenham could hijack another planned Manchester United move with Bournemouth's Antoine Semenyo now a concrete target.
The Lilywhites and Bournemouth likely have a good relationship following the latter's record £65million sale of Dominic Solanke.

In terms of how much Semenyo could cost, Bournemouth are said to want a club-record fee which suggests anything in excess of £65million. Arsenal are also said to be interested in signing the Ghana international.
Tottenham could soon join Manchester United in the race to sign Bryan Mbeumo.
A deal for the Brentford star has been actively pursued over the last few days after it was made clear his preference was to seal a switch to Old Trafford.

However, his current manager Thomas Frank, is on the verge of replacing Ange Postecoglou as Spurs head coach with it therefore very likely a demand is made for his new club to sign a player he knows very well.
Tottenham are also in the market for a winger and working under a manager who knows how to get the best out of him, alongside playing Champions League football, could convince him to make a U-turn.
Victor Osimhen's future remains very open after he rejected a move to Saudi Pro League club Al-Hilal.
The Middle East outfit, just as they did with Bruno Fernandes, submitted a sizeable package to try and tempt him to join in time for the Club World Cup.

However, he turned down that switch and that has seen Manchester United remain in the race for his signature. Despite so much talk about his future, his latest Instagram posts certainly suggests he is remaining calm.
A post shared by Victor Osimhen ( MFR ) (@victorosimhen9)
Viktor Gyokeres is said to be unhappy after Sporting CP shifted their transfer stance.
The Swede is expected to depart this summer with Manchester United one of many clubs being linked and now a fresh update has emerged in Portuguese news outlet Record regading his future.
It claims that the striker is not happy with the Sporting hierarchy amid continued speculation about his future.
Their report adds that Sporting are now asking for a higher fee than the supposed value of the gentlemen's agreement reached between the two parties earlier this year.
This development could impact United's pursuit of the 27-year-old unless big exits are sanctioned or Sporting ease down on that stance.
Hello and welcome back to our Manchester United transfer live blog!
Bryan Mbeumo, Victor Osimhen, Viktor Gyokeres, Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford continue to be the names trending around Old Trafford.
For the latest news on all of those big names and much more, be sure to stay tuned as regular transfer updates will come throughout the day!
It is understood that United have joined a host of clubs looking at Udinese defender Oumar Solet.
The Mirror claims that Juventus, West Ham, Inter Milan and Napoli have also been watching the French centre-back this summer.
Udinese are thought to want more than £30m for their defender.
Osimhen is determined to leave Napoli permanently this summer and the Serie A champions are determined to get a deal done.
It is understood that Al Hilal managed to shake hands on a £63m transfer for Osimhen so that is likely how much United would need to spend for him.
Before they can do that, unless they abandon the move for Mbeumo, United will need to complete sales to boost their budget.
Manchester United may be hoping that Chelsea can complete a £50 million transfer this summer, with the move having a domino effect on other possible transfers.

United have already been active in the transfer window, completing the £62.5 million move for Matheus Cunha. They are also actively pursuing a deal for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo with a deal possibly costing around £60 million.

Ruben Amorim is keen to add further to his squad over the coming weeks as he prepares for his first full season in charge of the club. But the business that can be done may come down to the sales that the club manage to make.
READ MORE HERE
Outgoing centre-back Jack Kingdon has thanked everyone associated with United after it was announced he will be leaving the club when his contract expires.
United issued their end-of-season retained list on Monday afternoon, confirming nine players will leave the club when their contracts expire at the end of June.

Kingdon is one of six academy players to have been informed he will be leaving Old Trafford, meaning he will be attempting to write the next chapter of his career elsewhere. He spent five years at United after joining the club as a 15-year-old from Morecambe.
MORE HERE.
We reported last week that Bryan Mbeumo is keen to move to United this summer despite their lack of Champions League football.
This was before his current manager Thomas Frank was heavily linked with replacing Ange Postecoglou at Tottenham Hotspur.

Despite this, journalist Fabrizio Romano has told GiveMeSport that the Cameroonian is still keen to do business with United and is not willing to negotiate with other clubs, including Spurs, just yet.
News that United could be looking at a Gyokeres deal adds some concern as to whether or not Bryan Mbeumo remains a target for the club.
Despite having their first bid rejected, United are still thought to be confident of completing a deal.
United have confirmed that the following players have been released by the club following the end of the season
** Heaton remains in contract talks with United over a new deal.
MORE HERE.
United are believed to be exploring the conditions of a potential deal through intermediaries.
This is claimed to be United's first step towards a bid for Gyokeres this summer.
According to Tuttosport, United and Arsenal's interest in Victor Osimhen convinced the striker to reject Al Hilal's transfer offer.
It is understood that the Nigerian rejected a move to the Middle East on Sunday despite the Saudi Pro League club booking Osimhen's medical and flights for it.
Juventus are also interested in Osimhen but it is believed the hope of moving to the Premier League convinced the 26-year-old to hold out for a better offer.
According to TyC Sports reporter Gaston Edul, Garnacho's preference this summer is to remain in the Premier League.
Currently, it is understood that both Chelsea and Arsenal have issued enquiries into the forward's availability.
Napoli also reportedly remain interested having had a bid rejected for the winger in January.
Hello and welcome to the United transfer blog this Monday afternoon.
My name is Jack Flintham and will be with you through to this evening bringing you all the latest United news to start off the week.
We are going to begin by looking at Alejandro Garnacho and the latest reports surrounding his exit...
United are among the favourites to complete a move for Viktor Gyokeres this season, according to odds from out friends at Betfair.
The bookmakers have United priced at 8/11, with Arsenal at 9/2.
Atletico Madrid are at 10/3, while Liverpool or any Saudi Pro League team are priced at 4/1.
United would like to sign a striker, central midfielder and a goalkeeper alongside Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo this transfer window, as reported by the Guardian.
However, a move for all the players won't be possible without significant sales. Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Alejandro Garnacho are among those who are available for transfer.
It seems that Thomas Frank is closing in on a move to Spurs, which could have an impact on United's pursuit of Bryan Mbeumo, if reports are to be believed.
Journalist Ben Jacobs reports that the Brentford boss has now verbally agreed terms with Tottenham over becoming their new manager with the Dane 'expected' to replace Ange Postecoglou.
Reports claim that once in situ, Frank will try and hijack United's deal for Mbeumo.
Manchester United are one of the clubs showing an interest in Lille goalkeeper Lucas Chevalier this summer, according to reports in France.
Le Parisien report that United as well as Man City are showing an interest in the 23-year-old.
It is however said that the goalkeeper will not come cheap, his current deal expires in 2027, but Lille have not yet given up hope of the player signing an extension.
The price tag is said to be as high as €70 million (£58.9m).

headline: Bryan Mbeumo transfer could be bad news for Ruben Amorim favourite at Manchester United
body: Slowly but surely an image of how Manchester United could line up at the start of next season is developing.

Just over a week into the first stage of the summer transfer window and United have already wrapped up the signing of Wolves star Matheus Cunha. They have now set their sights on attempting to lure Brentford ace Bryan Mbeumo to Old Trafford as well.

To say United have made an ambitious start to head coach Ruben Amorim's first summer at the helm is an understatement. Cunha has arrived in M16 on the back of a 17-goal season in all competitions and Mbeumo netted 20 goals in the Premier League in 2024/25.

Identified as a top target several months ago, Cunha has arrived at Old Trafford with the task of almost certainly filling the left-sided No.10 position. If Mbeumo is successfully drafted in, it is thought he will occupy the right-sided No.10 position.

United have finished each of the last two Premier League campaigns with a negative goal difference, meaning their decision to try and bolster their attack as their first port of call this summer is a wise one.

Cunha, and possibly Mbeumo, would immediately add the goals that have been missing in previous seasons. Between them, they have plundered 56 goals between them since the beginning of the 2023/24 Premier League campaign.

In addition to adding goals to the team, Cunha and Mbeumo would also strengthen the levels of competition for places. Despite Amorim often struggling to find a consistent and productive attack this term, it was not through a lack of options.
United have a cluster of players who are capable of playing in either of the two No.10 positions: Bruno Fernandes, Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount, Alejandro Garnacho, Joshua Zirkzee, Cunha and Amad.

With Garnacho facing the prospect of being sold and Fernandes looking increasingly likely to be deployed as a No.8 next season amid Cunha's arrival, the size of that list will reduce, meaning Mainoo, Mount, Zirkzee, Cunha, Amad and potentially Mbeumo will all be challenging to start in the two No.10 positions.
Of course, each of those players are versatile to some degree but the majority will believe that is their best position in Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system.
If Mbeumo signs, Amad is highly likely to be installed as United's first-choice right wing-back and operate from out wide. However, Mainoo and Mount will be less assured of regular starting berths.

Mainoo has struggled to force his way into the starting XI this calendar year, with his one-minute cameo against Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final feeling rather telling about where he currently sits in Amorim's plans.
Meanwhile, Mount started the last four games of the season, including the Europa League final. Amorim is a massive fan of the former Chelsea man.
"I'm so happy for him," Amorim said after Mount scored twice in United's 4-1 win over Athletic Club last month. "He is such a player. He works really hard, he has quality.
"When you see that kind of guy like Mason working hard every day, eating well, having ice baths, when you have this kind of player you just want to help him."

The fact he started the final four games of the season as one of the two No.10s confirmed once and for all just how highly Amorim rates him. Injuries, however, plagued his first two seasons at the club, restricting him to just 46 appearances across all competitions.

Well-versed in a three at the back formation from his Chelsea days, it is understandable why Amorim is so fond of the 26-year-old. He is a tailor-made fit for his system and his understanding of what to do and where to be when United don't have possession is admirable.

However, if United land Mbeumo, it is hard to see where Mount fits into Amorim's first-choice starting XI. Mbeumo and Cunha would occupy the two spots reserved for the No.10s and Mount is not a central-midfielder in this system.
Competition for places is healthy and should never be frowned upon, but one of Amorim's most valued players may have to settle for a place on the bench.

headline: Manchester United could have four players fighting for the same position next season
body: The prospect of Manchester United playing as few as 40 games next season means head coach Ruben Amorim will not have to rotate quite as frequently as he did last season.

United's failure to qualify for the Champions League via the Europa League means they will only have domestic matters to focus on in 2025/26 in the form of the Premier League, the FA Cup and the League Cup.
Not since 2014/15 have United had a season without European football. They successfully managed to get back into the Champions League for 2015/16 that season by securing a top four finish.
Once again, United's main objective next season has to be securing European football for 2026/27. European participation brings a whole host of benefits, not least financially.

However, one of the biggest advantages of United being out of Europe next season is that Amorim will not have as congested a fixture schedule to deal with, meaning there will be a lot of free midweeks to spend on the training ground.
As encouraging as that could be as a collective, some individuals may find game time much harder to come by. United need to reduce the size of their squad and a whole host of departures are expected.

However, the bulk of the exits United are planning for are in the attacking department, with Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony being identified as priority sales. Alejandro Garnacho has also been told he can leave for the right price.

The prospect of each member of that aforementioned quartet being sold will generate funds for United to reinvest elsewhere in the squad. They plan to sign Bryan Mbeumo, a striker, a midfielder and a goalkeeper.

One area which is not expected to be strengthened, though, is the centre-back department. After signing Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro last summer and then Ayden Heaven in February, United are very well stocked at the back.

Despite the impending exits of out-of-contract duo Jonny Evans and Victor Lindelof, United still have five first-team centre-backs they can all upon in the shape of Harry Maguire, Lisandro Martinez, De Ligt, Yoro and Heaven. Noussair Mazraoui and Luke Shaw are also equally comfortable operating in the back-three.

Injury issues meant United didn't finish the 2024/25 campaign with a settled defence, meaning pre-season is set to determine who will make up Amorim's first-choice back-three come the start of the new campaign in August.

Amorim could find himself with four players believing they are worthy of occupying the left-sided centre-back spot. Martinez, both before and after United switched to a back-three, was the club's main left-sided centre-back.
However, his season-ending ACL injury meant the position was occupied by several different faces in the second half of the season, including Yoro, Heaven and Shaw.

Despite originally being signed to operate as the right-sided centre-back in a back-four, United's mid-season shift to a back-three was expected to see Yoro become Amorim's first-choice option on the right of his three-man defence. However, the Frenchman arguably produced his best performances for United so far on the opposite side of the defence.

"[Being] right footed is more easy for me sometimes on the right, but I really like to play on the left," Yoro said earlier this year. "When I go inside, I can put a long ball to the striker, or in the middle, so I like both sides. It's no problem for me."
Yoro has the capacity to become a staple in United's defence for many years to come, likewise Heaven, who has not put a foot wrong since arriving from Arsenal earlier this year.

Martinez will be hungry to reclaim the left-sided centre-back spot and make up for lost time once he recovers from his injury. He was just getting to grips with the demands of Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system prior to his injury and will be keen to demonstrate his ball-playing credentials.
If he can stay fit, Shaw will also be keen to muscle in on the conversation for a starting berth. Now that United operate with wing-backs, his main route into the team is at centre-back.
With no obvious winner, pre-season could decide who wins the race to become Amorim's first-choice left-sided centre-back.

headline: Manchester United announce retained list as nine released and contract talks confirmed
body: Manchester United have issued their end-of-season retained list, confirming they are in talks with goalkeeper Tom Heaton over a new contract.
Despite only making three appearances since returning to United in the summer of 2021, the 39-year-old is a valued member of the dressing room and has been part of the leadership group.

United's decision to offer Heaton a new deal highlights uncertainty around the goalkeeping department. Head coach Ruben Amorim wants to recruit a new shot-stopper this summer to challenge Andre Onana for the No.1 spot.
United had already confirmed Jonny Evans, Victor Lindelof and Christian Eriksen would be leaving the club when their deals expire on June 30.

They each made their final competitive appearances for the club in the 2-0 win over Aston Villa on the final day of the Premier League season last month. Eriksen marked the occasion by scoring a second half penalty.
Elsewhere, United have confirmed academy players Hubert Graczyk, Jack Kingdon, Sam Murray, Tom Myles, James Nolan and Tom Wooster will also be released when their contracts expire this summer.

Kingdon and Murray spent time away from Old Trafford on loan last season, enjoying stints at Rochdale and Inverness Caledonian Thistle respectively, as did young goalkeepers Myles and Wooster, who had spells at Runcorn Linnets and Farsley Celtic respectively.
Meanwhile, United have also confirmed youngster Ashton Missin has been offered a contract to stay at the club. He signed his first professional contract at Old Trafford last summer.
